title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, and powers. It also includes provisions for a Board, Director of National Transportation Research, personnel matters, regional centers, and authorization of appropriations. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Federal investment in transportation research is only about 1% of overall government spending on transportation programs, despite a 40% increase in funding for transportation programs in the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century. Despite a 40% increase in funding for transportation programs, resources for transportation research and development have remained flat. There is a lack of adequate funding for long-term transportation research goals, and the competitive award of research funding is seen as the best approach to address strategic research needs. The diversity of transportation research programs poses challenges in effectively meeting the needs of different customers. The diversity of transportation research programs poses challenges in effectively meeting the needs of different customers, making priority setting difficult. Increasing Federal investment in long-range transportation research is crucial to ensure the United States transportation system meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals. To enhance the United States transportation system, it is important to increase Federal investment in long-range transportation planning, support competitive research into systemic transportation issues, coordinate research programs, facilitate data exchange, and establish nationwide priorities. The curr_chunk focuses on sharing research and development data among interested parties and establishing nationwide priorities in Federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include sharing research and development data and establishing nationwide priorities in Federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for promoting research and development in multimodal transportation. It will also support projects with long-term significance and clear public benefits where private investment is not optimal. The National Center for Transportation Solutions awards grants to research institutions for long-term transportation objectives and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the US. The National Center for Transportation Solutions in the United States serves as a clearinghouse of information for transportation research, consults with Department of Transportation officials, and coordinates research programs with public and private groups. It evaluates government transportation research programs and provides an annual report. The Director of National Transportation Research evaluates US government transportation research programs and submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on multimodal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members provide minority views and recommendations related to multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members provide minority views and recommendations related to multimodal transportation. SEC. 5 establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with the Senate majority leader. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with Senate leaders. Members must represent various professions and sectors. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with Senate leaders. Members must represent various professions and occupations in the public and private sectors, a broad range of regions in the United States, and possess skills appropriate to the Center's functions. Initial appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with terms specified. Members of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board shall be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. They will serve staggered terms, with six members serving for six years and five members serving for four years. No member can serve for more than two consecutive terms. Members of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board serve staggered terms, with six members serving for six years, five members for four years, and five members for two years. Terms do not expire during election years. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members serve staggered terms of different lengths. Vacancies on the Board do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board members serve staggered terms of different lengths. Vacancies do not affect powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board shall select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members, who shall serve for 2-year terms. The Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board are selected from among its members and serve 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms for the Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research is established. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board for a six-year term. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, is a nonvoting member of the Board for a six-year term, and may not exceed a certain salary rate. The Center is organized under SEC. 7. The Center, organized under SEC. 7, is divided into the following divisions: Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, Transportation Economics, and other divisions as determined by the Board. Each division has a committee for recommendations and consultation. Each division under SEC. 7 has a committee composed of at least five members who serve two-year terms and elect a Chairman annually. Each division committee under SEC. 7 has at least five members serving two-year terms. The committee elects a Chairman annually and sets its own procedures within Board restrictions. SEC. 8 outlines the powers of the center. The Board and division committees have the authority to conduct hearings, gather testimony and evidence, and obtain information from Federal agencies to fulfill the requirements of this Act. Upon request, Federal departments or agencies must provide the requested information to the Board or division committee. The Board and division committees can conduct hearings, gather evidence, and obtain information from Federal agencies. Federal departments must provide requested information to the Board or division committee. The Board is authorized to enter contracts and agreements, including sole source agreements with entities like the National Academy of Sciences. The Board and division committees can use the United States mails like other Federal departments. The Board and division committees can accept gifts and publish research results. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for submitting strategic and annual plans, as well as developing the Center's annual budget. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff responsibilities include submitting strategic and annual plans, developing the annual budget, administering programs, providing staff support to the Board, reporting progress to the Board, and coordinating with other agencies. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for Center personnel can be fixed by the Director without regard to certain pay regulations, with a maximum rate of pay set at level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for personnel may not exceed the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Director of the Center can appoint staff without following civil service laws and compensation for personnel is capped at the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Volunteer services can be accepted without following certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director will award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States by September 30, 2005. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with clear public benefits and where private investment is necessary due to market failures. The northeast regional center established under this section will be located in one of the 5 States with the highest levels of traffic congestion in the United States. The State must have high traffic congestion levels based on the ratio of urban National Highway System roads to lane miles. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
